Namely, the earth element, water element, fire element, wind element, space element, and consciousness element.
Bhikkhus!
It is in reference to this that it is said: 'A person has six elements.'
Bhikkhus!
What is the cause and reason why a person has six bases for contact?

Bhikkhus, the eye contacts and sees forms, the ear contacts and hears sounds, the nose contacts and smells scents, the tongue contacts and tastes flavors, the body contacts and feels tangibles, the mind contacts and cognizes mental objects.
Bhikkhus!
It is in reference to this that it is said: 'A person has six bases for contact.'
Bhikkhus!
What is the cause and reason why a person has eighteen mental preoccupations?

Bhikkhus, when the eye sees forms, one dwells contemplating forms as pleasing, one dwells contemplating forms as unpleasing, one dwells contemplating forms as neither pleasing nor unpleasing. Thus, with regard to the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind, one cognizes mental objects, dwells contemplating mental objects as pleasing, dwells contemplating mental objects as unpleasing, dwells contemplating mental objects as neither pleasing nor unpleasing.
Bhikkhus!
These six contemplations of pleasure, six contemplations of displeasure, and six contemplations of equanimity, combined, are eighteen preoccupations.
Bhiká¹£us!
People have eighteen kinds of mental activity, and for this reason it is said.
Bhiká¹£us!
People have four abodes, and what is the meaning of this saying?
Namely, the abode of true reality, the abode of wisdom, the abode of giving, and the abode of cessation.
Bhiká¹£us!
People have four abodes, and for this reason it is said.
What is the wisdom of diligence for bhiká¹£us?
If there is a bhiká¹£u who discerns the elements of the body, now in my body there is an internal earth element that is born, what is this?
Namely, hair, body hair, nails, teeth, coarse and fine skin, skin, flesh, bones, muscles, kidneys, heart, liver, lungs, spleen, large intestine, small intestine, and feces.
In this way, the rest in the body is internal, internally included, solid, solidity abiding internally, received at birth, this is called the internal earth element by bhiká¹£us.
Bhiká¹£us!
If there is an internal earth element and an external earth element, they are all collectively called the earth element. None of them is mine, I am not them, and neither is there a spirit.
Thus, contemplating and knowing it as it truly is, the mind is not attached to this earth element. This is called the wisdom of non-negligence of a bhiká¹£u.
Furthermore, the wisdom of non-negligence of a bhiká¹£u.
If a bhiká¹£u discerns the body element, thinking 'In my body now, there is an internal water element that is born,' what is it?

It refers to brain membranes, tears, sweat, mucus, saliva, pus, blood, fat, marrow, spittle, serum, and urine. In this body, there are other internal things, internal water, the nature of water, internally moist, born and received. This is called the internal water element of a bhiká¹£u.
Bhiká¹£us!
If there is an internal water element and an external water element, they are all collectively called the water element. None of them is mine, I am not them, and neither is there a spirit.
Thus, contemplating and knowing it as it truly is, the mind is not attached to this water element. This is called the wisdom of non-negligence of a bhiká¹£u.
Furthermore, bhiká¹£us, the wisdom of non-negligence.
If a bhiká¹£u discerns this bodily element, now in my body there is an internal fire element that is born, what is this?

It is called the heat of the body, the warmth of the body, the fever of the body, the heat of the body, which digests food and drink. In this way, the rest of the body is internally contained, the fire that is internally included, the nature of fire is hot, born and received. This is called the internal fire element of a bhiká¹£u.
Bhiká¹£us!
If there is an internal fire element and an external fire element, they are all collectively called the fire element. None of them belong to me, I do not belong to them, and they are not my self.
Thus, contemplating and knowing them as they truly are, the mind is not attached to this fire element. This is called the wisdom of diligence of a bhiká¹£u.
Furthermore, bhiká¹£us, the wisdom of diligence.
If a bhiká¹£u discerns the body element, thinking 'In my body now there is an internal wind element that is born,' what is it?
Namely, upper wind, lower wind, rib wind, contraction wind, kicking wind, non-path wind, joint wind, exhalation wind, inhalation wind.
In this way, the remaining winds in the body, the internal, internal-comprising winds, the nature of wind, internal movement, born and received, are called the internal wind element by bhiká¹£us.
Bhiká¹£us!
If there is an internal wind element and an external wind element, they are all collectively called the wind element. None of them belong to me, I do not belong to them, and they are not my self.
Thus, contemplating and knowing them as they truly are, the mind is not attached to this wind element. This is called the wisdom of diligence of a bhiká¹£u.
Furthermore, the wisdom of diligence of a bhiká¹£u.
If a bhiká¹£u discerns the body element, thinking 'In my body now, there is an internal space element that is born,' what is this?
It refers to the space in the eyes, ears, nose, mouth, throat, and the movement of food and drink being swallowed and slowly passing through.
In this way, the remaining space in the body is internally included, and the space within is not covered by flesh, skin, bones, or sinews. This is called the internal space element by a bhiká¹£u.
Bhiká¹£us!
If there is an internal space element and an external space element, they are all collectively called the space element. None of them is mine, I am not them, and neither is there a spirit.
Thus, observing with wisdom, knowing them as they really are, the mind is not attached to this space element. This is called the wisdom of non-negligence of a bhiká¹£u.

If there is a bhiká¹£u who knows these five elements as they really are, and having known them as they really are, his mind is not attached to them and is liberated, then there is only remaining consciousness. What kind of consciousness is this?
Consciousness of pleasure, consciousness of pain, consciousness of joy, consciousness of sorrow, and consciousness of equanimity.
Bhiká¹£us!
Because of the contact of pleasant feeling, the perception of pleasure arises. That perception of pleasure, having perceived pleasure, then knows the perception of pleasure.

If there is a bhiká¹£u who extinguishes this contact of pleasant feeling, having extinguished this contact of pleasant feeling, if there is a perception of pleasure arising from the contact of pleasant feeling, it also ceases, stops, and is known to be cool.
Bhiká¹£us!

Because of the pleasure of suffering, the perception of suffering arises. That perception of suffering, having perceived the perception of suffering, one knows the perception of the perception of suffering.

If a bhiká¹£u extinguishes this pleasure of suffering, having extinguished this pleasure of suffering, if there is the perception of suffering that arises from the pleasure of suffering, that also ceases, stops, and is known to be cool.
Bhiká¹£us!
Because of the pleasure of joy, the perception of joy arises. That perception of joy, having perceived the perception of joy, one knows the perception of the perception of joy.

If a bhiká¹£u extinguishes this pleasure of joy, having extinguished this pleasure of joy, if there is the perception of joy that arises from the pleasure of joy, that also ceases, stops, and is known to be cool.
Bhiká¹£us!
Because of the pleasure of sorrow, the perception of sorrow arises. That perception of sorrow, having perceived the perception of sorrow, one knows the perception of the perception of sorrow.

If a bhiká¹£u extinguishes this feeling of sorrow and pleasure, and after extinguishing this feeling of sorrow and pleasure, if there is a feeling of sorrow that arises from sorrow and pleasure, that too is extinguished, ceases, and is known to be cool.
Bhiká¹£us!

Because of the feeling of equanimity, the perception of equanimity arises. That perception is the perception of equanimity. Having perceived the perception of equanimity, one knows the perception of equanimity.

If a bhiká¹£u extinguishes this feeling of equanimity, and after extinguishing this feeling of equanimity, if there is a perception of equanimity that arises from the feeling of equanimity, that too is extinguished, ceases, and is known to be cool.
Bhiká¹£us!

Because of each feeling, each perception arises. After extinguishing each feeling, each perception is also extinguished. One knows that this perception arises from feeling, that feeling is the basis, that feeling is the practice, that feeling gives rise to feeling, and that feeling is the foremost, relying on feeling to function.
Bhiká¹£us!
It is just like a fire-drill, because of the drill and the person's skillful heat, fire is produced.
Bhiká¹£us!

The many scattered trees and woods are separated from each other. If fire arises from them, the number of fires is hotter than the number of births and sensations. When they all cease and stop, it is cold firewood.
Thus, bhiká¹£us!

Because of the various contacts, various sensations arise. When the various contacts cease, the various sensations also cease. One knows that this sensation arises from contact, that contact is the basis of contact, and that contact is the cause of contact. It arises from contact and is headed by contact, relying on contact to function.
If a bhiká¹£u is not attached to these three sensations and is liberated, that bhiká¹£u only abides in equanimity, which is extremely pure.
Bhiká¹£us!
That bhiká¹£u thinks like this:
'I move this pure equanimity into the immeasurable space, cultivate this mind in this way, rely on it, abide in it, establish it, take it as a condition, and bind it to it.'

I will transfer this pure equanimity into the sphere of infinite consciousness, the sphere of nothingness, and the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception. I will cultivate this mind, rely on it, abide in it, establish it, and be bound to it.'
Bhiká¹£us!
It is just like a skilled goldsmith who burns gold, forges it to make it extremely thin, and repeatedly adds fire to it, refining it again and again to make it pure, extremely pliable, and radiant.
Bhiká¹£us!

When this gold is repeatedly refined by the goldsmith, making it pure, extremely pliable, and radiant, then the goldsmith can use it to make whatever he wishes, whether it be a fine silk garment, a new garment adorned with various colors, a finger ring, an armlet, a necklace, or a jeweled garland.
In the same way, bhiká¹£us!
That bhiká¹£u thinks like this:
'I transfer this pure equanimity into the sphere of infinite space, cultivating this mind, relying on it, abiding in it, establishing it, taking it as an object, and being bound to it.

I transfer this pure equanimity into the sphere of infinite consciousness, the sphere of nothingness, and the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception, cultivating this mind, relying on it, abiding in it, establishing it, taking it as an object, and being bound to it.'
That bhiká¹£u further thought like this:
'This pure equanimity of mine, relying on the sphere of infinite space, is therefore conditioned.
If it is conditioned, then it is impermanent. If it is impermanent, then it is suffering.
If it is suffering, then one knows suffering. Having known suffering, one abandons it here and does not transfer it into the sphere of infinite space again.
This pure equanimity of mine, relying on the sphere of infinite consciousness, the sphere of nothingness, and the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception, is therefore conditioned.
If it is conditioned, then it is impermanent. If it is impermanent, then it is suffering.

If it is suffering, then one knows suffering. Having known suffering, one abandons it here and does not move into the base of infinite consciousness, the base of nothingness, or the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.

If there are bhiká¹£us who contemplate these four bases with wisdom, know them as they really are, and do not accomplish or move their minds into them,

It is like a burning lamp, dependent on oil and wick. If no one replenishes the oil and continues the wick, it will be extinguished and will not continue burning.

This is called the first right wisdom of bhiká¹£us, namely, reaching the ultimate cessation. A bhiká¹£u who has exhausted the defilements accomplishes that, and accomplishes the first right wisdom.

This liberation abides in the truth, and cannot be moved. The truth is called the Dharma, and false speech is called the Dharma of falsehood.

Sutra on Distinguishing the Six Sense Bases (163), Middle Length Ä€gama Sutras, Fundamental Distinguishing Collection, Sutra on Distinguishing the Six Sense Bases, second of the fourth distinguishing recitation. I have heard thus:
Once, the Buddha was traveling in the country of Shravasti, staying in the Jeta Grove, Anathapindika's Park.
At that time, the World-Honored One told the bhikshus:

I will expound the Dharma for you, wonderful in the beginning, wonderful in the middle, and wonderful in the end, with meaning and phrasing, complete and pure, revealing the pure life, namely the Sutra on Distinguishing the Six Sense Bases.
Listen attentively, listen attentively, and consider it well.
At that time, the bhikshus said:
World-Honored One!
We will surely receive the teaching.
The Buddha said:

You should know the six sense bases as internal, you should know the six sense contact-points as internal, you should know the eighteen mental activities as internal, you should know the thirty-six knives as internal, you should know the accomplishment of cutting them off as internal, you should know the immeasurable teachings as internal, there are three mental abidings, namely what is practiced by the noble ones.

Having practiced what is practiced by the noble ones, the assembly can be taught, the unsurpassed tamer of those to be tamed, the tamer of those to be tamed in all directions, this is called the analysis of the six sense bases sutra matter.
Why is it said, 'You should know the six sense bases as internal'?
It means the eye sense base, the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind sense bases, 'You should know the six sense bases as internal' is said for this reason.
Why is it said, 'You should know the six sense contact-points as internal'?ğŸ”½Here it is said:

It means that eye-contact is for seeing forms, ear-contact is for hearing sounds, nose-contact is for smelling fragrances, tongue-contact is for tasting flavors, body-contact is for feeling tactile objects, and mind-contact is for cognizing mental phenomena. The six sense bases should be known as internal. For this reason, it is said.
The eighteen mental activities should be known as internal. For what reason is this said?

A monk, having seen forms with the eye, abides in joy in distinguishing forms, abides in sorrow in distinguishing forms, abides in equanimity in distinguishing forms. Thus, with regard to the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind cognizing mental phenomena, he abides in joy in distinguishing mental phenomena, abides in sorrow in distinguishing mental phenomena, abides in equanimity in distinguishing mental phenomena. These are called the six joys in distinguishing, the six sorrows in distinguishing, and the six equanimities in distinguishing, collectively called the eighteen mental activities. The eighteen mental activities should be known as internal. For this reason, it is said.
The thirty-six knives should be known as internal. For what reason is this said?

There are six kinds of joy based on attachment, six kinds of joy based on non-desire, six kinds of sorrow based on attachment, six kinds of sorrow based on non-desire, and six kinds of equanimity based on attachment and six kinds of equanimity based on non-desire.
What are the six kinds of joy based on attachment?
What are the six kinds of joy based on non-desire?
Having seen forms with the eye, joy arises, which should be known as twofold, either based on attachment or based on non-desire.
What is joy based on attachment?

When the eye knows forms that are delightful, the mind thinks of and loves the forms, being associated with the pleasure of desire. One who has not obtained [the forms] desires to obtain them, and having obtained them, one recollects and gives rise to joy. Such joy is called joy based on attachment.
What is joy based on non-desire?

Knowing that forms are impermanent, changing, ending, without desire, ceasing, and subsiding, and recollecting that all forms in the past and present are impermanent, suffering, and subject to cessation, one gives rise to joy. Such joy is called joy based on non-desire.
In the same way, the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind know dharmas and give rise to joy, which should be known as twofold, either based on attachment or based on non-desire.
What is joy based on attachment?

When the mind knows dharmas that can be joyfully contemplated, it gives rise to love and desire, and one wishes to obtain what has not been obtained, and upon obtaining it, one recollects and gives rise to joy. This kind of joy is called joy based on attachment.
What is joy based on non-desire?

Knowing dharmas are impermanent, changing, ending, without desire, ceasing, and extinguishing, and recollecting all dharmas in the past and present are impermanent, suffering, and subject to cessation, one gives rise to joy. This kind of joy is called joy based on non-desire.
What are the six kinds of sorrow based on attachment?
What are the six kinds of sorrow based on non-desire?
When the eye sees forms and gives rise to sorrow, it should be known as twofold, either based on attachment or based on non-desire.
What is sorrow based on attachment?

When the eye knows a pleasing form, the mind thinks of and loves the form, and is associated with desire. One who has not attained it cannot attain it, and what has been attained passes away, disperses, disappears, and changes, giving rise to sorrow. Such sorrow is called sorrow based on attachment.
What is sorrow based on non-desire?

Knowing that form is impermanent, changing, ending, free from desire, ceasing, and previously and now all forms are impermanent, suffering, and subject to cessation, having remembered this, one thinks:
When will I attain and enjoy that place,
where the sages attain and enjoy?
This is the supreme fear of fulfilling one's wishes. Knowing suffering, sorrow arises.
Such sorrow is called sorrow based on non-desire.
In this way, when the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind know dharmas, sorrow arises. One should know that there are two kinds, either based on attachment or based on non-desire.
What is sorrow based on attachment?ğŸ”½...

The mind knows the desirable dharmas, the mind thinks of, loves, and is associated with desire for the dharmas, what has not been obtained is not obtained, what has been obtained is past, scattered, destroyed, changed, and gives rise to sorrow. Such sorrow is called sorrow based on attachment.
What is sorrow based on non-desire?

Knowing dharmas are impermanent, changing, ending, without desire, ceasing, and extinguished, all dharmas in the past and present are impermanent, suffering, and subject to cessation. Having remembered this, one thinks:
When will I attain and enjoy that place?
It is said:
The place where the sages attain and enjoy.
This is called the supreme touch of hope and fear, knowing suffering and giving rise to sorrow.
Such sorrow is called sorrow based on non-desire.
What are the six abandonments based on attachment?
What are the six abandonments based on non-desire?
Having seen forms with the eye, one gives rise to abandonment, which should be known as twofold, either based on attachment or based on non-desire.

When the eye knows form and gives rise to equanimity, the foolish and ignorant ordinary person, who is not equal, not well-versed, and lacks wisdom, has equanimity towards form and is not apart from form. This is called equanimity based on attachment.
